description.h:p: In this single agent learning version of the Blind Jumper model there is an agent (the "jumper") that is not able to see the size of the barrier over which it has to jump, and there is another agent (the "speaker") that is able to see the size of the barrier and communicates this to the jumper using the fixed symbols "A", "B" and "C" for the sizes 1, 2 and 3. The Blind Jumper first has to learn which symbol stands for which size. He can perceive the success or failure of a jump (a jump fails if it is too short or too long), and then update his symbol interpretation function accordingly.

This problem description has been extracted from the paper Beyond the Chinese Room: The blind jumper - Self-organised semantics and pragmatics on the computer by Peter Fleissner and Gregor Fleissner. There is also an implementation of this model by its authors.
The not yet licensed blind jumper cartoon is from http://www.iclipart.com.

documentation.description: Each RL rule defines a number of relevant situation types (based on the triggering perception event and one of a finite number of state conditions) and enumerates them with the help of a state index. This state index corresponds to the row of the learning automata (LA) matrix. The action event scheduled by the rule has a parameter for which the rule is using a finite number of values corresponding to the number of columns of the LA matrix. By using a lookup function searching for the maximum value in the matrix row determined by the current state index, the RL rule associates an agent state with a specific action (given by the combination of the rule's action event type and the value of the action parameter).

When the jumper receives a Tell message with one of the distance symbols "A", "B" and "C" (corresponding to a state index of 1, 2 or 3), it stores this state index in the attribute currentJumpRuleStateIndex. Then it looks up the maximum value in the row of the success probability matrix given by this index and stores the column number of this value in the attribute currentActionParameterValueIndex. Finally, it jumps with a distance corresponding to this index.

When the jumper receives the Success reinforcement signal, it updates its success probability matrix accordingly, i.e. the matrix value corresponding to the current state and the chosen action parameter value will be increased relativeley to the other values of the same row.

When the jumper receives the Failure reinforcement signal, it updates its success probability matrix accordingly, i.e. the matrix value corresponding to the current state and the chosen action parameter value will be decreased relativeley to the other values of the same row.
When the speaker perceives a new barrier with size 1-3, it sends a Tell message with a distance symbol corresponding to this parameter value.

The "blind jumper" is not able to see the size
of the barrier over which it has to jump, as opposed to
the "speaker" who tries to communicate this
to the blind jumper. However, both agents first have
to learn which symbols to use for communicating
the size of the barrier.
